Name: Aquaculture Production
Description: Difference in aquaculture production volume and value by country. High refers to increased production. Low refers to decreased production.

Name: Baseline Water Stress
Resource Name: Aqueduct Global Maps 2.1 Baseline water stress
Description: Ratio of total annual water withdrawals to total available annual renewable supply, accounting for upstream consumptive use. High refers to greater water stress. Low refers to lower water stress.

Name: Carbon Stocks
Resource Name: Global 1-degree Maps of Forest Area, Carbon Stocks, and Biomass, 1950-2015 - ORNL DAAC.
Description: Forest biomass data at 1-degree resolution for the period 1950-2010. High refers to large carbon stock. Low refers to low carbon stock.

Name: Change in Precipitation Seasonality
Resource Name: MerraClim Maximum Change in Precipitation Seasonality
Description: Change in maximum precipitation seasonality from the 1980s to 2000s. High refers to more extreme changes in seasonality. Low refers to little or no change.

Name: Change in Temperature Seasonality
Resource Name: MerraClim Maximum Change in Temperature Seasonality
Description: Change in maximum temperature seasonality from the 1980s to 2000s. High refers to more extreme changes in seasonality. Low refers to little or no change.

Name: Change in Wind Speed
Description: Change in wind speed from 1958 to 2017. High refers to increases in wind speed. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Drought Severity
Description: Average of the months of dryness from 1901 to 2008. High refers to greater drought severity. Low refers to lower severity.

Name: Earthquakes
Resource Name: Extent of built environments from Global Terrestrial Human Footprint maps by Venter et al. 2016.
Description: Global Seismic Hazard Map. High refers to higher seismic hazard. Low refers to areas with little or no hazard.

Name: Extent of Built Environment
Description: Difference in the extent of built environments from 1993 to 2009. High refers to increased extent of infrastructure. Low refers to areas that have either not changed or have a lower extent.

Name: Fire Density
Description: Average of fire density over the period 1997-2010. High refers to greater fire density. Low refers to lower fire density.

Name: Fisheries Production
Description: Difference in the volume of aquatic species caught by country for all commercial, industrial, recreational and subsistence purposes. High refers to increased catch volumes. Low refers to decreased catch volumes.

Name: Flood Occurrence
Description: Count of the number of floods recorded from 1985-2011. High refers to a greater number of floods. Low refers to fewer or no recorded floods.

Name: Gain in Agricultural Area
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Gain in Forested Area
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Gain in Urban Area
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Ground Water Stress
Resource Name: Aqueduct Global Maps 2.1 Ground water stress
Description: Relative ratio of groundwater withdrawal to recharge rate. Values above one indicate where unsustainable groundwater consumption could affect groundwater availability and groundwater-dependent ecosystems. High refers to greater stress. Low refers to lower stress.

Name: Habitat Intactness
Resource Name: Map of Biodiversity Intactness Index - Natural History Museum Data Portal.
Description: Modelled average abundance of originally-present species relative to their abundance in an intact ecosystem.

Name: Human Migration
Description: Global data by country on international migrant stock difference between 2017 and 1990. High refers to an increase in migrants. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Inorganic Pollution
Resource Name: Inorganic pollution data from Cumulative Human Impact maps by Halpern et al. 2015.
Description: Difference in inorganic pollution at coastlines from 2008 to 2013. High refers to an increase in pollution levels. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Invasive Species
Description: Number of invasive species per country. High refers to higher numbers of invasive species. Low refers to lower numbers of invasive species.

Name: Lake Quality
Resource Name: Water Quality for Major Watersheds, UN Environment/DEWA/GRID-Geneva
Description: Total dissolved solids (TDS) for the major world lakes. High refers to higher levels of TDS. Low refers to lower levels of TDS.

Name: Landforms
Description: Landform classification.

Name: Landslide Frequency Caused by Earthquakes
Resource Name: Frequency of landslides caused by earthquakes, International Centre for Geohazards/NGI
Description: Expected annual probability of occurrence of a potentially destructive landslide event caused by an earthquake x 1,000,000. High refers to greater probability. Low refers to lower probability.

Name: Landslide Frequency Caused by Precipitation
Resource Name: Frequency of landslides caused by precipitation, International Centre for Geohazards/NGI
Description: Expected annual probability and percentage of pixel of occurrence of a potentially destructive landslide event caused by precipitation x 1,000,000. High refers to greater probability. Low refers to lower probability.

Name: Lithology
Description: Lithological classifications.

Name: Livestock Density
Resource Name: Gridded Livestock of the World v2.0, Robinson et al. 2014.
Description: Summed density of cattle, ducks, pigs, sheep, chickens and goats using livestock units. High refers to greater density. Low refers to lower density.

Name: Loss of Agricultural Area
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Loss of Forested Area
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Loss of Urban Area
Resource Name: Extent of built environments from Global Terrestrial Human Footprint maps by Venter et al. 2016.
Description: Based on land use transitions data (high scenario) from 850 - 2015. High refers to a greater number of changes between land-use states. Low refers to fewer changes in states.

Name: Ocean Acidification
Resource Name: Ocean acidification data from Cumulative Human Impact maps by Halpern et al. 2015.
Description: Ocean acidification levels in 2013. High refers to an increase in acidification. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Ocean Pollution
Resource Name: Ocean pollution data from Cumulative Human Impact maps by Halpern et al. 2015.
Description: Difference in ocean pollution from 2008 to 2013. High refers to an increase in pollution levels. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Population Density
Resource Name: Gridded Population of the World, Version 4 (GPWv4): Population Density, Revision 10, CIESIN.
Description: Change in population density from 2000 to 2015. High refers to an increase in population density. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Precipitation Seasonality
Description: Maximum precipitation seasonality in the 2000s. High refers to an increase in maximum seasonality. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Range Rarity
Resource Name: IUCN Red List Species Range Rarity
Description: The range rarity map is based on IUCN Red List polygons (IUCN 2017) of mammals, amphibians and bird species where high values show that an area holds a large number of species and/or that the average ranges of the species present in the area are small, so that the cell represents a relatively high proportion of their range.

Name: River Quality
Resource Name: Water Quality for Major Watersheds, UN Environment/DEWA/GRID-Geneva
Description: Total dissolved solids (TDS) for 82 watersheds representing major world rivers, or smaller rivers that have regional significance. High refers to higher levels of TDS. Low refers to lower levels of TDS.

Name: Sea Level Rise
Resource Name: Sea level rise data from Cumulative Human Impact maps by Halpern et al. 2015.
Description: Sea level rise in 2013. High refers to higher rates of sea level rise. Low refers to lower rates.

Name: Sea Surface Temperature
Resource Name: Sea surface temperature data from Cumulative Human Impact maps by Halpern et al. 2015.
Description: Difference in sea surface temperature between 2008 and 2013. High refers to an increase in sea surface temperature. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Seafloor Geomorphology
Description: Ocean geomorphology classification.

Name: Shipping Activity
Resource Name: Global Shipping Activity from the World Maritime Organisation
Description: Top 5% of commercial shipping tracks for ships participating in the WMO Voluntary Observing Ships (VOS) program. High refers to greater shipping intensity. Low refers to lower intensity.

Name: Soil Degradation
Resource Name: Global Assessment of Human-induced Soil Degradation (GLASOD)
Description: Status of soil degradation in 1990 based on physiographic units and expert judgement. High refers to greater soil degradation. Low refers to little or no soil degradation.

Name: Storm Surge Events
Resource Name: A Storm Surge Database for the U.S. Gulf Coast.
Description: Location of storm surges for each ocean basin since 1880 as of February, 2015. High refers to a greater number of recorded surges. Low refers to fewer surges.

Name: Temperature Seasonality
Description: Maximum temperature seasonality in the 2000s. High refers to an increase in maximum seasonality. Low refers to no difference or a decrease.

Name: Variability in Water Supply
Description: Variation in water supply from year-to-year. High refers to greater inter-annual variability. Low refers to little or no variability.

Name: Volcanic events
Resource Name: Global Volcanism Program, 2013. Volcanoes of the World, v. 4.7.4. Smithsonian Institution.
Description: Volcanic events in the Holocene. High refers to a greater number of recorded volcanic events. Low refers to fewer or no events.

Name: Light pollution
Description: Location of man-made visible and infrared light at night. Brighter areas indicate greater light pollution. Darker areas indicate lower light pollution.

Name: Global Reservoirs and Dams - dams
Resource Name: Global Reservoir and Dam (GRanD), v1 - Dams
Description: Location of dams included in the Global Reservoir and Dam Database (GRandD).

Name: Global Reservoirs and Dams - reservoirs
Resource Name: Global Reservoir and Dam (GRanD), v1 - Reservoirs
Description: Location of reservoirs included in the Global Reservoir and Dam Database (GRandD).

Name: Monthly CO2 in the free troposphere
Resource Name: AIRS/Aqua L3 Monthly CO2 in the free troposphere
Description: Monthly mean CO2 level in the mid troposhere. High refers to greater levels of CO2. Low refers to lower levels of CO2.

Name: Fish catch in national waters per country
Description: Catch in Millions of tonnes (Mt) per country. High refers to greater catch. Low refers to lower catch.

Name: Global ambient air pollution PM2.5
Description: Mean concentration of particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns and below in the most recent reported year. Points are shown for selected cities and localities. Bigger points show higher concentration of particulate matter. Smaller points show lower concentration of particulate matter. The colour of the point denotes the change in concentration from the first reported year to the most recent reported year. A negative change represents a decrease in concentration and a positive change represents an increase.

Name: Global ambient air pollution PM10
Description: Mean concentration of particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns and below in the most recent reported year. Points are shown for selected cities and localities. Bigger points show higher concentration of particulate matter. Smaller points show lower concentration of particulate matter. The colour of the point denotes the change in concentration from the first reported year to the most recent reported year. A negative change represents a decrease in concentration and a positive change represents an increase.

Name: Solid waste per country
Description: Volumes of solid waste produced. High refers to greater volumes of solid waste. Low refers to lower volumes of solid waste.

Name: Global land cover data
Legend: ['Cropland', 'Plantations', 'Managed Pasture', 'Cropland / Pasture', 'Agriculture with forest', 'Agriculture with other vegetation', 'Agriculture / Forest mosaic', 'Agriculture / Other mosaic', 'Forest with agriculture', 'Other vegetation with agriculture', 'Agriculture / 2 other land cover types', 'Primarily Forest (>60%)', 'Primarily Grassland (>60%)', 'Other vegetation: wetlands, mangroves', 'Non-vegetated / Sparsely vegetated', 'In-land water', 'Ocean', 'Islands']
Description: Global map of land cover types.

Name: Water pollution data
Description: Displays areas that have been affected by hypoxia or eutrophication.

Name: Global water depletion (Aqueduct 3.0)
Resource Name: Aqueduct Global Maps 3.0 Data - Water depletion
Description: Ratio of total water consumption to available renewable water supplies. Higher values mean larger impact on local water supply and decreased water availability downstream. Lower values mean lower water depletion.

Name: Combined hotspots of natural capital depletion
Resource Name: Combined hotspots of natural capital depletion
Description: Overlapping hotspots of depletion of stocks of natural capital assets (atmosphere, water, soil and sediments, biodiversity) in terrestrial environments. Hotspots correspond to the top 20% values of depletion, where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation.

Name: Atmosphere depletion
Legend: ['Hotspots of depletion (highest 20% of values)', 'Higher depletion', 'Medium depletion', 'Lower depletion', 'Lowest depletion']
Description: Global relative rate of natural capital depletion of the atmosphere, measured through temperature anomalies and emissions of non-GHG pollutants. Depletion values were sorted from highest to lowest and split into 5 quantiles. The highest 20% relative depletion values correspond to hotspots, where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation.

Name: Biodiversity depletion
Legend: ['Hotspots of depletion (highest 20% of values)', 'Higher depletion', 'Medium depletion', 'Lower depletion', 'Lowest depletion']
Description: Global relative rate of natural capital depletion of biodiversity, measured through biodiversity intactness. Depletion values were sorted from highest to lowest and split into 5 quantiles. The highest 20% relative depletion values correspond to hotspots, where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation.

Name: Soil and sediments depletion
Legend: ['Hotspots of depletion (highest 20% of values)', 'Higher depletion', 'Medium depletion', 'Lower depletion', 'Lowest depletion']
Description: Global relative rate of natural capital depletion of soil and sediments, measured through soil erosion, change in soil salinity, and change in soil carbon stocks. Depletion values were sorted from highest to lowest and split into 5 quantiles. The highest 20% relative depletion values correspond to hotspots, where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation.

Name: Water depletion
Legend: ['Hotspots of depletion (highest 20% of values)', 'Higher depletion', 'Medium depletion', 'Lower depletion', 'Lowest depletion']
Description: Global relative rate of natural capital depletion of water, measured through high baseline water stress, lack of sanitation and high coastal eutrophication potential. Depletion values were sorted from highest to lowest and split into 5 quantiles. The highest 20% relative depletion values correspond to hotspots, where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation.

Name: Potential natural capital depletion
Legend: ['7 hotspots', '6 hotspots', '5 hotspots', '4 hotspots', '3 hotspots', '2 hotspots', '1 hotspot']
Description: Overlapping hotspots of potential depletion of natural capital assets (marine sediment carbon, coral reefs, cold corals, seagrasses, mangroves, saltmarshes, tidal flats, seamounts, cold seeps, and hydrothermal vents), where human activities will be associated with higher risks of ecosystem service loss or degradation. Hotspots of potential depletion correspond to an overlap between natural capital assets and high human pressure.
